Specific Comments on FAR Part 1:

The changes to FAR Part 1 have created two severe unintended consequences for my small business.

(1) The "Regulatory Sunset" (FAR 1.109) creates perpetual instability. The federal marketplace requires predictability. The provision that all non-statutory regulations—including the "Rule of Two" and all socioeconomic set-aside programs—will expire every four years unless renewed introduces a level of uncertainty that is toxic to investment and will discourage small businesses from entering or remaining in the market.

(2) The removal of former Subpart 1.5, "Agency and Public Participation," silences our voice. This action does not comport with the Administrative Procedure Act, which guarantees public participation in rulemaking. The practical effect of removing the formal process before a new one is legally established is to strip stakeholders of their right to due process. An informal feedback website is not a legally sufficient substitute.

Recommendation:

Immediately halt the implementation of the RFO via class deviations and re-engage with this process through the proper, transparent, and legally mandated notice-and-comment rulemaking process.

Restore the public participation procedures formerly in Subpart 1.5.

Repeal FAR 1.109, the "Regulatory Sunset," entirely or, at a minimum, amend it to explicitly exempt all of FAR Part 19 and its implementing clauses from its scope to ensure program stability.

(2) The Flawed "Adopt First, Finalize Later" Implementation: The unprecedented use of rolling class deviations to implement massive, government-wide policy changes circumvents the transparent, legally-mandated notice-and-comment process required by the Administrative Procedure Act. This "adopt first, finalize later" approach denies stakeholders a meaningful opportunity to provide input before a rule takes effect, rendering the eventual rulemaking process performative rather than substantive.

(3) The Systemic Removal of Procedural Safeguards Dismantles the Small Business Safety Net: The RFO does not just change individual rules; it severs the connective tissue that links them together. By removing small business considerations from FAR Parts 10 (Market Research), 6 (Competition), and 11 (Describing Agency Needs), you have effectively created a procedural vacuum. Contracting officers are no longer explicitly prompted to consider a set-aside, consult with the SBA before bundling, or avoid unnecessarily restrictive schedules. The burden has been shifted from the government to the small business community to police the entire acquisition process, which is an unfair and unsustainable expectation.

(4) Direct Economic Harm to Local Communities: This is not just a regulatory issue; it is a significant economic issue with direct consequences for local economies and jobs in every congressional district. In my district ([Your Congressional District]), small businesses received [$ amount] in federal contracts last year, with [X]% of that coming from set-asides. Already, policies favoring contract consolidation have contributed to a [Y]% decline in the number of unique small business suppliers in my district over the last [Z] years. The RFO, by dismantling the very procedures that ensure local firms can compete, will only accelerate this decline, harming the industrial base and the economic health of our community.

(5) The Transfer of Risk to Contractors Will Increase Costs and Reduce Competition: The elimination of standard, predictable risk-allocation clauses—most notably the "Variation in Quantity" clause from FAR Part 11—is a direct financial threat to my business. This forces us to price for worst-case scenarios, which will either make our bids uncompetitive or increase the ultimate cost to the taxpayer. This change will drive small firms out of the market and reduce competition.---

Specific Comments on FAR Part 6:

FAR Part 6 governs how agencies determine whether a contract should be competed or not. The proposed changes allow agencies to proceed without triggering the small business “Rule of Two,” and they remove the long-standing connection between set-aside requirements and competition determinations.

(1) Deleting the “Rule of Two” as a Regulatory Trigger: The proposed revisions remove the requirement that contracting officers conduct market research and apply the Rule of Two to determine if small businesses can meet the need. Without this, the government can skip set-asides simply by proceeding under commercial or GSA methods. This subverts the statutory framework that mandates maximum practicable opportunity for small business participation.

(2) Shifting Language from “Shall” to “May”: The new language changes what was a requirement into a discretionary action. This eliminates the enforceable obligation to consider a set-aside first, opening the door to inconsistent implementation and reduced transparency.

Recommendation:

FAR 6.206 must retain the mandatory application of the Rule of Two prior to use of commercial procedures, GSA vehicles, or Best in Class contract vehicles. The discretion now granted to agencies under these revisions should be repealed or at minimum made subject to SBA review and protest.

Specific Comments on FAR Part 10:

FAR Part 10 governs how the government conducts market research — a process that has historically triggered many small business protections and set-asides.

(1) Removal of Small Business-Specific Research Requirements: The proposed language eliminates the mandate to determine whether small businesses can perform the work. This breaks the link between research and competition strategy and weakens the Rule of Two. Without this link, small businesses are more easily overlooked.

(2) The Language Now Allows “Narrow” or “Streamlined” Research: While efficiency is important, the proposed text enables agencies to define research as broadly or narrowly as they choose. This makes it harder for small businesses to be “found” and considered.

The regulation must preserve the requirement that contracting officers document and justify the results, and SBA must retain the right to challenge inadequate or biased market research findings.

Specific Comments on FAR Part 11:

FAR Part 11 defines how the government writes specifications and statements of work — it is where barriers to entry are often created.

(1) The Removal of the Variation in Quantity Clause: The proposed changes delete FAR 52.211-16, the clause that helps contractors manage risk when quantities are uncertain. Without this clause, contractors must bid based on worst-case assumptions, inflating prices or choosing not to bid at all. This favors large firms with greater financial buffers.

(2) Missing Language on Avoiding Unnecessarily Restrictive Specs: The old regulation emphasized the importance of not excluding capable vendors through unduly specific or proprietary requirements. The proposed language is silent on this — and that silence will encourage exclusionary practices.

Recommendation:

Restore FAR 52.211-16 as a standard clause, or explicitly require an alternative clause for quantity flexibility. Reintroduce the safeguard language instructing contracting officers to avoid unnecessarily restrictive statements of work unless justified and approved in writing.

FAR Part 18 governs emergency acquisitions — the special rules that apply when time is of the essence. While flexibility during emergencies is vital, the proposed changes eliminate long-standing safeguards that ensured rapid acquisition still followed competition principles.

(1) The Removal of Clauses That Applied Core Competition: The revised language drops previous references that required agencies to conduct simplified or streamlined competition even during urgency. This opens the door to increased sole sourcing.

(2) Lack of Transparency and Reporting Obligations: There is no requirement for agencies to report after-the-fact to explain whether competition was feasible. This reduces accountability and oversight.

Recommendation:

Maintain a requirement for streamlined competition unless impossible. Require post-award reporting to justify any use of sole source procedures during emergencies, including why small businesses were not considered.

Specific Comments on FAR Part 39:

FAR Part 39 covers acquisition of IT — a major and growing category of federal spending. The proposed changes weaken safeguards that helped level the playing field for smaller tech vendors.

(1) The Removal of Language Favoring Open Standards: The current FAR favors open standards and interoperability to prevent vendor lock-in. The proposed revisions delete that guidance, allowing more proprietary systems that exclude small integrators.

(2) No Mention of Section 508 or Accessibility: The revised Part 39 no longer mentions the requirement that IT acquisitions be accessible under Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act — a key issue for inclusive procurement.

Recommendation:

Restore language favoring open standards, avoid vendor lock-in, and explicitly include Section 508 requirements in all IT acquisitions.

FAR Part 34 governs major system acquisitions — the complex, long-term projects often led by large primes. The proposed changes continue a trend toward consolidation and remove language that previously emphasized opportunities for small business participation.

(1) The Removal of Phased Development Considerations: The previous FAR encouraged phased development strategies that allowed for modular design, prototyping, and participation by smaller firms. The revised language omits this, favoring large, bundled approaches.

(2) Weakening Oversight of Acquisition Strategies: The new version reduces accountability mechanisms that ensured small businesses were considered in the acquisition planning phase of major systems.

Recommendation:

Restore language requiring that acquisition strategies for major systems include consideration of small business subcontracting, prototyping opportunities, and modular design approaches. Explicitly instruct agencies to include SBA early in the acquisition strategy process.

Specific Comments on FAR Part 43:

FAR Part 43 deals with contract modifications — the changes that happen after a contract is awarded. This is often where bundling, cost creep, and scope changes exclude small businesses.

(1) The Removal of Notification and Documentation Requirements: The new language downplays the need to justify or explain contract changes. This enables quiet rebundling of scope, increasing size and complexity in ways that disadvantage small firms.

(2) Reduced SBA Visibility: When a contract that was once small business–friendly is modified, there should be a safeguard that notifies SBA or offers protest rights. The new rules remove this.

Recommendation:

Add language requiring that material scope modifications trigger re-evaluation of small business set-aside status, including potential SBA review. Require that significant changes be documented and publicly accessible via FPDS or SAM.gov.

Specific Comments on FAR Part 52:

FAR Part 52 includes the standard contract clauses used throughout the FAR. The proposed changes eliminate or weaken clauses that support small business protection, price fairness, and transparency.

(1) The Deletion of Small Business-Focused Clauses: The overhaul removes long-standing clauses that made size status, limitations on subcontracting, and nonmanufacturer rule requirements visible and enforceable. This undermines enforcement of the Small Business Act.

(2) The Shift to “Buying Guides” Instead of Contract Clauses: Some clauses have been replaced with informal language buried in agency-level buying guides or templates. These are not enforceable and reduce transparency and consistency.

Recommendation:

Reinstate critical clauses that enforce small business protections — particularly those connected to FAR Part 19. Clarify that buying guides cannot override regulatory clause requirements and that all FAR clause removals must undergo formal rulemaking.
